Context:
The Recreation Management in Gerontology program at the college focuses on the aging process from both a practical and theoretical perspective, with an emphasis on communication skills, business management, and gerontology. Students will learn how to use specialized software used in the sector for tasks such as data gathering and documentation, therapeutic approaches, and activity programming. Partner companies include Activity Pro, Cyber Seniors, and Dementiability. The program offers field placements at various settings including long-term care facilities, retirement homes, community-based service agencies, and adult day programs. Field education is offered in each semester, with career options upon graduation being abundant due to the increasing number of older adults in Canada. Some clinical or work placement partners may require students to show proof of full vaccination against COVID-19.

FACTUAL INFORMATION:
- The program focuses on both practical and theoretical perspectives of aging process.
- Students will learn interpersonal communication skills, business communication skills, and study gerontology.
- Partnered with leading industry companies for software training including Activity Pro, Cyber Seniors, and Dementiability.
- Offers field placements at long-term care facilities, retirement homes, community-based service agencies, and adult day programs.
- Career options include various settings with older adults.
- Increasing number of older adults in Canada creates demand for career opportunities in this field.
- Some clinical or work placement partners may require students to show proof of full vaccination against COVID-19.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Recreation Management in Gerontology Program C152 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
The Recreation Management in Gerontology program graduates can apply for a reduced time frame (approximately 12–18 months) to complete a B.A. in gerontology at Laurentian University with a GPA of 2.8 or higher. This degree can be completed through distance education or at the Laurentian campus in Sudbury. graduates with a B.A. in gerontology from Laurentian University can apply to complete the Recreation Management in Gerontology diploma in one year.

Graduates of health sciences programs who are interested in working in long-term care facilities can consider applying for the Interprofessional Complex and Long-Term Care (S417) postgraduate certificate, which is a two-semester program delivered online and on-demand to accommodate working professionals and includes a clinical field placement component.

The required courses for SEMESTER 1 of the S417 program include: COMM 1081 – Interpersonal Communication Skills, GERT 1004 – Recreation I: Therapeutic Interventions, GERT 1038 – Pre-Placement Seminar, GERT 1018 – Field Practice I, GERT 1035 – Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Disorders, GERT 1033 – Introduction to Gerontology, GERT 1010 – Aging in Place, GERT 1025 – Integrated Seminar I, and COMM 1000 – Introduction to College Communication (If necessary).

For more information about the Laurentian University application process, contact admissions@laurentian.ca. For information regarding the Recreation Management in Gerontology diploma program, email Pamela Gauci at pamela.gauci@georgebrown.ca.

Program Learning Outcomes:
- The graduate demonstrates the ability to function effectively as a member of an interprofessional team in the development and provision of health-promoting and life-enhancing services and programs for older adults.

- The graduate develops, coordinates, delivers and evaluates a variety of services/programs that enhance clients’ level of functioning and quality of life by applying relevant research and theory to practice.
- The graduate applies appropriate health and safety protocols in order to protect the health, safety and well-being of their clients, their co-workers and themselves.
- The graduate communicates effectively using a variety of therapeutic methods.

Context:
The text provides information about a program offered at George Brown College for older adult activation. Here are the key facts extracted from the text:

1. The text mentions that communication techniques and therapeutic methods should be used effectively while adhering to privacy and freedom of information legislation.
2. Professionals are expected to identify, select, and use appropriate resources to meet the needs of older adults in various settings.
3. Programs must operate in compliance with relevant policies, legislation, and standards of practice for services to older adults.
4. Ethical and professional standards in the field of activation gerontology must be maintained as set out by relevant professional bodies.
5. Accessible, inclusive, and responsive programs and services are promoted for individuals, groups, families, and communities.
6. Physical, financial, and human resources must be managed effectively to coordinate services for older adults.
7. The tuition fees for domestic students is CAD 3,947.00 for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2022. The international student tuition fee is CAD 17,595.00 for the same period.
8. Financial assistance is available through OSAP (Ontario Student Assistance Program) for eligible applicants.
9. Applicants must have an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent and a minimum grade of 60% in grade 12 English (C or U). Information sessions are recommended, and mature students may take the Admissions Assessment for English or upgrade their skills to apply.
10. Admission decisions are based on academic credit, and it is recommended that applicants accumulate at least 40 volunteer hours working with older adults prior to applying.

Context:
* Mature students have the option to take the Admissions Assessment for English or upgrade to achieve required credits in English.
* Meeting minimum requirements does not guarantee admission to a program.
* College or university credits may qualify for course exemptions, more information can be found on the Transfer Guide.
* International Students should refer to the International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements.
* Upon acceptance into a program, students must meet mandatory pre-placement health requirements which may take up to four months to complete.
* All costs associated with health requirements are the student's responsibility.
* Students must have a Police Vulnerable Sector Check completed and renewed annually for field or clinical placements.
* The check process takes two to three months, but can take up to eight months under certain circumstances.
* Fees for the police record check vary and are the student's responsibility.
* Students unable to provide a clear police reference check may not be able to complete the program or secure employment.
